explanation:
OS_object_token_t: The function takes OS_object_token_t *token and both reads and writes fields of *token. The struct definition is required to determine exactly which members are modified (so the pointer cannot be const) and whether any members are themselves pointers that might need const qualification.
(type of) token->lock_key (e.g., OS_lock_key_t): token->lock_key.key_value is written. The concrete type and its members are needed to know whether assignment/mutation occurs and whether that member could be const-qualified instead of the whole token pointer.
OS_objtype_state_t: The function obtains objtype as an OS_objtype_state_t * and mutates objtype->transaction_count and objtype->owner_key. The struct definition shows which members are modified, proving that the objtype pointer cannot be const if these members must be updated.
OS_objtype_state: The global array (or symbol) from which &OS_objtype_state[token->obj_type] is taken. Its declaration shows whether the array elements are modifiable storage (i.e., non-const) and confirms that taking a non-const pointer is necessary.
OS_OBJECT_TYPE_USER and OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE: These constants/macros control the entry/exit of the main if block. Knowing their types/values is necessary to determine whether the token pointer is ever only read (would allow const) or if the write-path is reachable.
OS_LOCK_KEY_FIXED_VALUE: Used to compute token->lock_key.key_value. The macro/type is needed to understand the assignment semantics and whether it requires mutable storage.
OS_OBJECT_ID_RESERVED: Assigned to self_task_id in one branch. Its type/value is needed to confirm no hidden mutation/aliasing implications that could affect whether fields (e.g., lock_key) must be modified.

Together, these symbols let an analyzer determine which members are mutated and therefore whether the pointers in the function could be declared to point to const-qualified types without violating behavior (the MISRA guidance).
